sentence-detokenized: FOOTBALL - JAPAN'S LUCKY WIN, CHINA'S SURPRISING DEFEAT.
Japan opened their Asia Cup title defence with a lucky 2-1 win over Syria in their Group C match on Friday.
However, in the second match of the group, China's luck deserted them and they surprisingly lost to Uzbekistan 2-0.

China controlled most of the match and missed several chances until the 78th minute, when Uzbek striker Igor Shkvyrin took advantage of a defender's errant header and sent the ball into an empty net past the onrushing Chinese goalkeeper.
Oleg Shatsyuk scored in injury time with an unstoppable left-footed shot from outside the penalty area.
The former Soviet republic played in the Asia Cup finals for the first time.
Although Uzbekistan won the title at the Asian Games two years ago, it is an underdog in the finals.
Two goals, which came after defensive errors in the last six minutes, allowed Japan to take all three points from their opening clash with Syria.

The winning goal was scored in the 88th minute by Takuya Takagi, who rose up and headed after a Hiroshige Yanagimoto pass into the Syrian goal, which goalkeeper Salem Bitar appeared to cover but then let slip into the net.
It was Syria's second costly mistake in four minutes.
In the 84th minute, defender Hassan Abbas took a long ball into the penalty area but could only direct it into the top corner of Bitara's goal.
Nader Jokhadar sent Syria into the lead in the seventh minute.
Japan then laid siege to the Syrian penalty area for most of the match, but rarely penetrated the Syrian defence.
Whenever they did, Bitar pulled off great saves.
Japan coach Shu Kamo said: "The Syrian own goal proved to be a lucky one.
The Syrians scored early and then played defensively and took long balls, which made it difficult for us.'
Japan, which co-hosted the 2002 World Cup and is ranked 20th in the world by FIFA, is the favourite to win the title here.
On Saturday, the hosts UAE and Kuwait and South Korea and Indonesia will play in Group A.
All four teams have one point from one game.
RUGBY UNION - CUTTITTA RETURNS TO THE ITALIAN NATIONAL TEAM AFTER ONE YEAR.
in a friendly against Scotland at Murrayfield on Friday, more than a year after the 30-year-old winger announced he was quitting after disagreements in the selection process.
Cuttitta, who coach George Coste says is certain to start on Saturday, was included in a 21-man squad that was missing only two players from the team that England beat 54-21 at Twickenham last month.
Stefano Bordon is out through illness and Coste said he missed back-rower Corrado Covi, who was called up for the England game after five years out of the national team.
Cuttitta announced his retirement after the 1995 World Cup when he disliked being left out of the Italy team that faced England in the preliminary group.
Coste said he approached the player two months ago about his return.
"The World Cup ended badly," Coste said.
"I thought it would be helpful to have him back, and he said he would be available.
I think now is the right time for him to come back. "

Javier Pertile, Paolo Vaccari, Marcello Cuttitta, Ivan Francescato, Leandro Manteri, Diego Dominguez, Francesco Mazzariol, Alessandro Troncon, Orazio Arancio, Andrea Sgorlon, Massimo Giovanelli, Carlo Checchinato, Walter Cristofoletto, Franco Properzi Curti, Carlo Orlandi, Massimo Cuttitta, Giambatista Croci, Gianluca Guidi, Nicola Mazzucato, Alessandro Moscardi, Andrea Castellani.
FOOTBALL - JAPAN WINS OVER SYRIA THANKS TO LATE GOALS.
Two goals in the last six minutes gave Japan an unexpected 2-1 victory over Syria on Friday.
In the 88th minute of the Group C match, Takuya Takagi scored when goalkeeper Salem Bitar fumbled a flawless performance and let the ball slip under his body.
It was the second mistake by the Syrian defence in four minutes.
In the 84th minute, defender Hassan Abbas took a long ball into the penalty area but could only direct it into the top corner of Bitara's goal.
Syria took the lead from its first serious attack in the seventh minute.
Nader Jokhadar headed into the top right corner of Kenichi Shimokawa's goal following a cross from the right by Ammar Awad.
Japan then laid siege to the Syrian penalty area, and in the 16th minute a goal was disallowed for offside.
A minute later, Bitar made a good double save, first blocking Kazuyoshi Miura's header and then blocking Takagi's follow-up shot.
In the 37th minute, Bitar again saved well from Miura when he turned away his header after a corner kick.
Japan started the second half actively, but Bitar robbed them of an equaliser when he dived to his right to save from Naoki Soma in the 53rd minute.

Japan: 19 - Kenichi Shimokawa, 2 - Hiroshige Yanagimoto, 3 - Naoki Soma, 4 - Masami Ihara, 5 - Norio Omura, 6 - Motohiro Yamaguchi, 8 - Masakiyo Maezono (7 - Yasuto Honda 71), 9 - Takuya Takagi, 10 - Hiroshi Nanami, 11 - Kazuyoshi Miura, 15 - Hiroaki Morishima (14 - Masayuki Okano 75).

FOOTBALL - RESULTS OF THE SECOND ROUND OF THE ENGLISH CUP.
Dutch striker Reggie Blinker had his indefinite suspension lifted by FIFA on Friday and was expected to return to Sheffield Wednesday's line-up against Liverpool on Saturday.
Blinker has missed his club's last two games after FIFA imposed a worldwide ban on him for signing contracts with Wednesday and Udinese while he was playing for Feyenoord.
At a meeting in Barcelona, FIFA's Committee on the Status of Players ruled that although the Udinese document is valid in principle, it cannot be legally protected.
According to the commission, the Italian club broke the rules by not informing Feyenoord, with whom the player had a contract.
Blinker was fined 75,000 Swiss francs ($57,600) for failing to inform the English club of his previous involvement with Udinese.
FOOTBALL - LEEDS " BOWYER FINED FOR BEING IN A FAST FOOD RESTAURANT.
Leeds England under-21 striker Lee Bowyer was fined 4,500 pounds ($7,400) on Friday for hurling chairs at restaurant staff during a disturbance at a McDonald's fast food restaurant.
Bowyer, 19, who was caught on security cameras during the crime, pleaded guilty to a charge of battery at a court in London.
He has been fined and ordered to pay a total of £175 to two staff members who were injured in an October altercation at a restaurant in east London.
Leeds has already fined Bowyer 4,000 pounds ($6,600) and warned him that a repeat of his criminal behaviour could cost him a place in the team.
Bowyer, who transferred to the Yorkshire club in August for 3.5 million pounds ($5.8 million), was scheduled to start against Middlesbrough on Saturday.

RUGBY UNION - LITTLE MISSING CAMPESE FAREWELL.
Midfielder Jason Little will miss Saturday's Australia's final game of the tour against the Barbarians at Twickenham.
Little has decided not to risk aggravating the knee injury that has sidelined him for much of the tour, and is replaced by fellow Queenslander Daniel Herbert.
Owen Finegan has recovered from the injury he suffered in last weekend's Test against Wales and has retained his place in the back row ahead of Daniel Manu.

The Wallabies are looking for their 13th win in a row to end their European tour with a 100% record, but they also want to turn on the style and bid a fitting farewell to David Campes in his last game in Australian colours.
The Wallabies are not currently planning any special presentation of the 34-year-old winger, but a full house of 75,000 spectators will still gather in the hope of witnessing one last magical moment.
Campese will be up against a familiar foe in Barbarians captain Rob Andrew, the man who inflicted defeat on Australia in the quarter-finals of the World Cup in Cape Town with his last drop-goal.
"Campo is hugely popular in this country and the public have loved him since 1984 when he first played here," said Andrew, who is likely to make his last appearance at Twickenham.
On the tour, Australia won all four Tests against Italy, Scotland, Ireland and Wales, scoring 414 points with an average of almost 35 points per game.

League commitments have limited the Barbarians' selection options, but they still boast 13 international players, including England defender Tim Stimpson and recalled winger Tony Underwood, and All Black forwards Ian Jones and Norm Hewitt.

FOOTBALL - PLAYERS WITHOUT QUALIFICATION CALLED UP FOR THE MATCH WITH MACEDONIA.
Romania's coach Anghel Iordanescu on Friday called up three non-qualifiers to the squad that will face Macedonia in World Cup qualifying next week.

Midfielder Valentin Stefan and striker Viorel Ion of Otelul Galati and defender Liviu Ciobotariu of National Bucharest are the newcomers for the European group eight finals, which will take place on 14 December in Macedonia.
Iordanescu said he chose them because of their good performance in the domestic championship, in which National Bucharest is first and Otelul Galati third. "
I think it's fair to give them a chance," he told reporters.
Defending league champions Steaua Bucharest, who finished last in their Champions League group in the European Cup, have only two players in their squad.
Attacking midfielder Adrian Ilie, who recently transferred from Steaua to Galatasaray in Turkey, is sent off after two yellow cards.
Defenders - Dan Petrescu, Daniel Prodan, Anton Dobos, Cornel Papura, Liviu Ciobotariu, Tibor Selymess, Iulian Filipescu.

CRICKET - LARA IS HAVING ANOTHER MISERABLE DAY.
Australia gave Brian Lara another reason for unhappiness when they beat the West Indies in the opening match of the limited-overs World Series on Friday.
Lara, who was booked for misconduct on Wednesday, was sent off for five, extending his disappointing form on tour.
Australia, which leads the five-Test series 2-0, overcame the West Indies' total of 172 by eight balls to end a run of six consecutive one-day defeats.
All-rounder Greg Blewett steered his side to a comfortable victory with an unbeaten 57 in 90 balls to the delight of the 42,442 crowd.
Man of the Match Blewett came onto the court with a 70-2 overall record and hit three fours in 129 minutes of play.
His crucial fifth-wicket partnership with fellow all-rounder Stuart Law, who scored 21, added 71 from 85 balls.
Lara looked out of sorts during his brief time on the field, and then managed to catch a simple strike to Shane Warne at midfield.
West Indies tour manager Clive Lloyd apologised for Lara's behaviour on Tuesday.
He (Lara) told Australia coach Geoff Marsh that wicketkeeper Ian Healy was not welcome in the visitors' dressing room.
The Melbourne crowd was clearly angered by the incident and loudly heckled the West Indies vice-captain as he walked to midfield.
It was left to fellow left-hander Shivnarine Chanderpaul to hold the innings together with a gritty 54 despite the handicap of an injured groin.
Chanderpaul was forced to rely on runners for most of his inning after he was injured while returning to his spot to avoid being run out.
The other team participating in the World Series tournament is Pakistan, who will arrive in Australia later this month.

CRICKET - LARA EXPERIENCES ANOTHER ORDEAL ON HER AUSTRALIAN TOUR.

West Indian batsman Brian Lara suffered another blow on his Australian tour after he was already punished for misconduct when he was cheaply dismissed in the first limited-overs match against Australia on Friday.
Lara, who earned a stern rebuke from his own tour management after a tantrum against Australian wicketkeeper Ian Healy, scored five runs to extend his poor form with the bat.
The West Indian vice-captain struggled for timing during his 36-minute stay on the field before chipping the ball from medium-paced Tom Moody straight to Shane Warne at mid-wicket.
West Indies were 53 for two in 15 overs when rain stopped play at the Melbourne Cricket Ground after captain Courtney Walsh won the toss and elected to bat.
Lara's outburst three days ago has apparently pitted a section of the Australian public against him.
As he walked to the goal, he was greeted by loud cheers from a section of the audience.
Several times during his performance, the audience collectively chanted obscene chants against him.

Tour manager Clive Lloyd on Wednesday apologised for Lara's behaviour when he clashed with Australia coach Geoff Marsh in the opposition dressing room to protest his dismissal in Tuesday's second Test.
Lloyd did not specify what form the disciplinary action would take.
Lara, who holds the record for the highest score in Test and first-class cricket, was unhappy with Healy's role in the incident and disputed that the ball was passed to the Australian wicketkeeper.
Australia won the match at the Sydney ground by 124 runs to take a 2-0 lead in the five-Test series after Lara failed in both innings.
Since the West Indies' arrival in Australia five weeks ago, Lara has yet to score a hundred.
The managements of both the West Indies and Australia teams played down the incident and stressed that relations between the two sides were not adversely affected in any way.
Pakistan, who arrive next week, are the third team in the triangular World Series tournament.
CRICKET - WEST INDIES AFTER WINNING THE TOSS AT BAT.
West Indies captain Courtney Walsh opted to bat after winning the first match of the World Series in the limited-overs competition against Australia at the Melbourne Cricket Ground on Friday.
